objectives: Understand the difference between direct and indirect speech
Learn the rules for converting direct speech into indirect speech
Practice changing tenses, pronouns, and time/place words correctly
Apply conversion rules to different sentence types like statements, questions, and commands

topics.title: Introduction to Direct and Indirect Speech

sections.text: Direct Speech is the exact words someone said. We use quotation marks ( "..." ) to show the speaker's actual words. It's like quoting someone directly. The verb that introduces the speech, like 'said' or 'asked', is called the reporting verb.

examples.label: Simple Statement
examples.value: He said, "I am going to the market."

examples.label: Question
examples.value: She asked, "Where are you going?"

examples.label: Command
examples.value: The teacher said, "Open your books."

examples.label: Statement with name
examples.value: Raju said, "My father is a farmer."

examples.label: To a person
examples.value: She said to me, "You are my best friend."

examples.label: Simple fact
examples.value: The farmer said, "The crops need rain."

examples.label: Question about time
examples.value: He asked, "What time is it?"

examples.label: Request
examples.value: My brother said to me, "Please help me with my homework."

examples.label: Future plan
examples.value: They said, "We will visit the temple tomorrow."

examples.label: Past event
examples.value: She said, "I saw a snake yesterday."

examples.label: Ability
examples.value: He said, "I can swim across the river."

examples.label: Opinion
examples.value: The villager said, "This year's harvest is good."

examples.label: Shouting
examples.value: The man shouted, "Help! There is a fire!"

examples.label: Replying
examples.value: The student replied, "I have finished my work."

examples.label: Expressing a feeling
examples.value: Mother said, "I am very proud of you."

examples.label: A universal truth
examples.value: The science teacher said, "Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius."

usage_examples: Tip: Always use quotation marks to enclose the speaker's exact words.
Tip: The first word inside the quotation marks always starts with a capital letter.
Tip: A comma is usually placed before the starting quotation mark.
Tip: Direct speech makes stories and conversations feel more real and immediate.

sections.text: Indirect Speech (also called Reported Speech) is when we report what someone said without using their exact words. We do not use quotation marks. We often use the word 'that' to introduce the reported words. In indirect speech, tenses, pronouns, and words showing time and place often change.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: He said, "I am going to the market."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: He said that he was going to the market.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: She asked, "Where are you going?"

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: She asked where I was going.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: The teacher said, "Open your books."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: The teacher ordered the students to open their books.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: Raju said, "My father is a farmer."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: Raju said that his father was a farmer.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: She said to me, "You are my best friend."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: She told me that I was her best friend.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: They said, "We will visit the temple tomorrow."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: They said that they would visit the temple the next day.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: The children said, "We are playing now."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: The children said that they were playing then.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: He said, "I can help you."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: He said that he could help me.

usage_examples: Tip: Quotation marks are removed in indirect speech.
Tip: The word 'that' is often used to connect the reporting verb with the reported speech.
Tip: The tense of the verb in the reported speech usually changes (moves back in time).
Tip: Pronouns and time/place words also change to reflect the new perspective.
Tip: Indirect speech is very common when telling a story or reporting a past conversation.

sections.text: When the reporting verb (e.g., 'said', 'told') is in the past tense, the tense of the verb inside the quotation marks usually changes. This is called 'backshifting'. For example, Present Simple becomes Past Simple. However, if the reported statement is a universal truth or a fact, the tense does not change.

examples.label: Present Simple -> Past Simple
examples.value: He said, "I work in a field." -> He said that he worked in a field.

examples.label: Present Simple -> Past Simple
examples.value: She said, "My sister cooks well." -> She said that her sister cooked well.

examples.label: Present Continuous -> Past Continuous
examples.value: She said, "I am washing clothes." -> She said that she was washing clothes.

examples.label: Present Continuous -> Past Continuous
examples.value: The boys said, "We are playing cricket." -> The boys said that they were playing cricket.

examples.label: Present Perfect -> Past Perfect
examples.value: They said, "We have finished our work." -> They said that they had finished their work.

examples.label: Present Perfect -> Past Perfect
examples.value: She said, "He has not come yet." -> She said that he had not come yet.

examples.label: Past Simple -> Past Perfect
examples.value: He said, "I bought a cow yesterday." -> He said that he had bought a cow the previous day.

examples.label: Past Simple -> Past Perfect
examples.value: She said, "The train arrived on time." -> She said that the train had arrived on time.

examples.label: Future (will) -> Conditional (would)
examples.value: She said, "I will go to the city." -> She said that she would go to the city.

examples.label: Can -> Could
examples.value: He said, "I can swim." -> He said that he could swim.

examples.label: May -> Might
examples.value: She said, "It may rain today." -> She said that it might rain that day.

examples.label: Must -> Had to
examples.value: He said, "I must complete my homework." -> He said that he had to complete his homework.

examples.label: Universal Truth (No change)
examples.value: The teacher said, "The sun rises in the east." -> The teacher said that the sun rises in the east.

examples.label: Habitual Fact (No change)
examples.value: He said, "I walk for an hour every morning." -> He said that he walks for an hour every morning.

usage_examples: Tip: Think of it as 'moving one step back' in time.
Tip: If the reporting verb is in the present (e.g., 'He says'), the tense does not change.
Tip: Universal truths, scientific facts, and habits remain in the present tense.

sections.text: Pronouns in direct speech change in indirect speech to match the subject and object of the sentence. First-person pronouns (I, me, my, we, us, our) change according to the subject of the reporting verb. Second-person pronouns (you, your) change according to the object of the reporting verb.

examples.label: First Person (I -> he/she)
examples.value: Ram said, "I am busy." -> Ram said that he was busy.

examples.label: First Person (I -> he/she)
examples.value: Geeta said, "I am writing a letter." -> Geeta said that she was writing a letter.

examples.label: First Person (my -> his/her)
examples.value: Sita said, "I love my village." -> Sita said that she loved her village.

examples.label: First Person (me -> him/her)
examples.value: He said, "My father gave me a pen." -> He said that his father had given him a pen.

examples.label: First Person (we -> they)
examples.value: They said, "We are playing." -> They said that they were playing.

examples.label: First Person (our -> their)
examples.value: The villagers said, "We love our village." -> The villagers said that they loved their village.

examples.label: Second Person (you -> me/him/her)
examples.value: He said to me, "You are kind." -> He told me that I was kind.

examples.label: Second Person (you -> me/him/her)
examples.value: She said to him, "You look tired." -> She told him that he looked tired.

examples.label: Second Person (your -> my/his/her)
examples.value: She said to him, "I have your book." -> She told him that she had his book.

examples.label: Second Person (your -> my/his/her)
examples.value: The teacher said to me, "Your work is good." -> The teacher told me that my work was good.

examples.label: Mixed Pronouns
examples.value: I said to you, "I will help you." -> I told you that I would help you.

examples.label: Mixed Pronouns 2
examples.value: She said to them, "You can use my pen." -> She told them that they could use her pen.

usage_examples: Tip: Always think from the perspective of the person reporting the speech.
Tip: 'I' changes to 'he' or 'she' depending on who said it.
Tip: 'You' changes depending on who the speech was directed to.
Tip: Third-person pronouns (he, she, it, they) do not change.

sections.text: Words that show nearness in time and place in direct speech change to words that show distance in indirect speech. This is because the time and place have changed from when the words were originally spoken.

examples.label: now -> then
examples.value: He said, "I am busy now." -> He said that he was busy then.

examples.label: today -> that day
examples.value: She said, "I will come today." -> She said that she would come that day.

examples.label: tonight -> that night
examples.value: He said, "We are having a party tonight." -> He said that they were having a party that night.

examples.label: yesterday -> the previous day / the day before
examples.value: They said, "We played a match yesterday." -> They said that they had played a match the previous day.

examples.label: tomorrow -> the next day / the following day
examples.value: He said, "I will leave tomorrow." -> He said that he would leave the next day.

examples.label: last week -> the previous week
examples.value: She said, "I was in the city last week." -> She said that she had been in the city the previous week.

examples.label: next month -> the following month
examples.value: They said, "The exams will start next month." -> They said that the exams would start the following month.

examples.label: here -> there
examples.value: She said, "Come here." -> She ordered me to go there.

examples.label: this -> that
examples.value: He said, "I like this book." -> He said that he liked that book.

examples.label: these -> those
examples.value: She said, "I want these mangoes." -> She said that she wanted those mangoes.

examples.label: ago -> before
examples.value: He said, "I met him two days ago." -> He said that he had met him two days before.

examples.label: thus -> so
examples.value: He said, "Thus, I passed the exam." -> He said that he had passed the exam so.

usage_examples: Tip: Think of 'here and now' becoming 'there and then'.
Tip: These changes are logical because you are reporting the speech at a later time and possibly a different place.

table.title: Changes in Time and Place Words
rows: the previous day / the day before
the next day / the following day

sections.text: To convert a statement (an assertive sentence), change the reporting verb 'said to' to 'told'. If there is no object after 'said', it remains 'said'. Use the conjunction 'that' to connect the reporting clause and the reported speech. Then apply all the general rules of changing tenses, pronouns, and time/place words.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: The farmer said, "I am sowing the seeds."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: The farmer said that he was sowing the seeds.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: My mother said to me, "You should work hard."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: My mother advised me that I should work hard.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: The boy said, "I have done my homework."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: The boy said that he had done his homework.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: She said to her friend, "I will wait for you here."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: She told her friend that she would wait for her there.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: Ravi said, "I went to the fair yesterday."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: Ravi said that he had gone to the fair the previous day.

examples.label: Direct
examples.value: The children said, "Our teacher is very kind."

examples.label: Indirect
examples.value: The children said that their teacher was very kind.

usage_examples: Tip: Remember, 'said to' changes to 'told'. You cannot say 'told to me'.
Tip: The use of 'that' is sometimes optional in informal English, but it's good practice to use it.

sections.text: To convert a question (an interrogative sentence), the reporting verb is changed to 'asked' or 'enquired'. The question is changed into a statement (subject comes before the verb). For Yes/No questions, we use 'if' or 'whether'. For Wh-questions (what, where, when, who, why, how), we use the same question word to connect. The question mark (?) is removed.

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: He said to me, "Are you a student?" -> He asked me if I was a student.

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: She said, "Can you help me?" -> She asked if I could help her.

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: The boy said to the girl, "Do you live here?" -> The boy asked the girl if she lived there.

examples.label: Wh-Question
examples.value: The man asked, "Where is the market?" -> The man enquired where the market was.

examples.label: Wh-Question
examples.value: I said to him, "Why are you late?" -> I asked him why he was late.

examples.label: Wh-Question
examples.value: The teacher asked the boy, "What is your name?" -> The teacher asked the boy what his name was.

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: He said, "Will you come tomorrow?" -> He asked if I would come the next day.

examples.label: Wh-Question
examples.value: She said to me, "How did you solve this problem?" -> She asked me how I had solved that problem.

examples.label: Yes/No Question
examples.value: Rina said to me, "Have you seen this movie?" -> Rina asked me if I had seen that movie.

usage_examples: Tip: The biggest change is turning the question into a statement. The verb comes after the subject (e.g., 'where the market was', not 'where was the market').
Tip: 'if' is more common in everyday speech; 'whether' is slightly more formal.
Tip: No question mark is used at the end of the indirect question.

sections.text: To convert commands and requests (imperative sentences), the reporting verb is changed to a word that shows the mood, like 'ordered', 'commanded', 'requested', 'advised', 'suggested', 'forbade', etc. We use the infinitive 'to' + the base form of the verb. For negative commands ('Don't...'), we use 'not to'.

examples.label: Command
examples.value: The captain said to the soldiers, "Fire!" -> The captain commanded the soldiers to fire.

examples.label: Request
examples.value: She said to me, "Please give me a glass of water." -> She requested me to give her a glass of water.

examples.label: Advice
examples.value: My father said, "Work hard." -> My father advised me to work hard.

examples.label: Advice
examples.value: The doctor said to the patient, "Take your medicines on time." -> The doctor advised the patient to take his medicines on time.

examples.label: Prohibition (Negative Command)
examples.value: The teacher said to the students, "Don't make a noise." -> The teacher forbade the students to make a noise. / The teacher ordered the students not to make a noise.

examples.label: Warning
examples.value: My mother said to me, "Don't go out in the sun." -> My mother warned me not to go out in the sun.

examples.label: Suggestion
examples.value: He said, "Let's go for a walk." -> He suggested that they should go for a walk.

examples.label: Simple Instruction
examples.value: He said to his friend, "Wait here till I return." -> He asked his friend to wait there till he returned.

examples.label: Begging
examples.value: The beggar said, "Please give me some food." -> The beggar begged for some food.

usage_examples: Tip: Choose the reporting verb carefully to match the tone of the original sentence (e.g., 'requested' for 'please').
Tip: The verb in the reported speech changes to the 'to-infinitive' form (e.g., 'open' becomes 'to open').
Tip: 'Forbade' is a strong word for 'don't'; 'asked... not to' or 'ordered... not to' are also common.
